Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 08:19PM bdavis wrote: Hi LAdies.. I wanted to chime in and cheer you on... I was part of the Jan 2011 Chemo group, starting TC on my 48th birthday. I had 6 rounds, and took a 10 day trip to St John between the 3rd and 4th treatments... I also worked full time and was promoted. I tell you this because chemo for most these days REALLY is doable. There are threads on here that you'll read with terrible side effects and never getting off the couch, but those are the exceptions... I read all that stuff and made a list of preventative measures I could take to make it through unscathed... or relatively unscathed. Yes, I lost my hair Yes, it is back and quite full That was my worst SE, but I had great wigs and got lots of compliments. I had a port and was very thankful, even for my 6 tx... I would not want to have been poked in the veins that many times... and I hear if you are borderline the chemo can leak and that is not good...  For the TC ladies, check out the threads: Taxotere is a Nightmare (but read it for suggestions, and don't be scared off) and Taxotere Toolbox (a thread with suggestions for combating SEs)  I would have my infusion usually on a Tuesday and then Neulasta on Thursday am... Friday was my day to rest (achey and tired) and by Saturday feeling much better. Good luck ladies and you'll be fine!!! And Jane... I had my port put in and waited to have the infusion... it took me about 2-3 days to get used to the port... just food for thought.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 09:32PM - edited Dec 27, 2011 09:35PM by bdavis So.. you had a lumpectomy? You mean the biopsy removed the lumps?? You will still need a sentinel node biopsy.. it is a surgical procedure  where they test the "main" node to see if the cancer spread to the nodes.They usually inject a dye in the breast by the lump(s) to see where it travels so they can identify the sentinel node. If the lumps have been removed, I am unsure how they know which one(s) are the SN.. so that would be a good question. Also, yes, you will need an oncologist... and if you need chemo its the medical oncologist who gives that to you, so you may not want to travel to Brooklyn for that... that could be very draining. You will also need a radiation onoclogist. If you just have the lumpectomy, you will need radiation. You can go just about anywhere for that. Princeton Radiation Oncology does it right at the hospital and has valet parking. I have heard of Dr McDermott... she used to work with Dr McManus (my BS) up in Somerset. My oncologist is Robert Fein in Somerset. He used to work at Sloan Kettering also, so that is one reason I chose him... plus Dr McManus recommended him... there is also the Cancer Institute up in New Brunswick - Dr Toppmeyer is an excellent oncologist...  I will PM you my phone number... please call me tomorrow and we can talk... It is all very daunting and you get this crash course in cancer. I have learned more than I ever wanted to know this past year.

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 09:46PM bdavis wrote: I should also add... since they did an excisional biopsy, ask them what the margins were... Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 09:10PM - edited Dec 27, 2011 09:18PM by bdavis If they are not in the same quadrant, you really have no choice about surgery.. that would really need to be a mastectomy. But if they are both in the same quadrant, you may be a candidate for a lumpectomy. I brought a friend with me who took notes and I had a long list of questions... She wants the genetic test because if you are positive, you also should have a bilateral MX since you'd have a 80% chance or something of more cancer... all these tests help determine what course of action she will take with you... so yes, make a list: 1) will she do an MRI to see if there is anything else (checking both breasts, in case she only did one the first time).. also helps determine type of surgery 2) What other characteristics did she discover from the biopsy, like grade (1-3), estrogen/progesterone pos or neg, Her2 pos or neg, size of tumors 3) does she think you need chemo first, before surgery or chemo at all? 4) will she do a sentinel node biopsy before surgery or during surgery? 5) if she finds the SN is positive, does she take more nodes then or will she go back in later (and do they do a preliminary pathology while you are in the OR)? 6)If you need chemo first, how quickly can you see an oncologist and who does she recommend? 7)if you have surgery first, how quickly can that happen? 8)If you need a mastectomy, what plastic surgeons does she work with? What types of recon do they do? Where does she cut you for the MX? Jenn... I live like 20 minutes from you... who are you seeing?

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 11:39PM bdavis wrote: Barry... about ultrasounds... they are only used to look for something of interest... they don't ever use the ultrasound to go looking for something. That's what the Mammogram/MRI is for... I had an MRI just to make sure I had nothing else going on before my lumpectomy, and low and behold, they found 2 areas of concern.. Luckily after an MRI-guided biopsy of those areas, they were benign. Had they been cancer, I would have been diagnosed with multi-centric cancer and had an MX... Important to have all the info BEFORE surgery, even if it means another MRI, with contrast.  Also, I had been told with MRI and ultrasound that my tumor was 1.2-1.5cm... reality was 1.9cm. AndI had been told I had clean nodes, from initial path report, but when the full path report came in, I had a micrometasis (trace cancer in the sentinel node). And I am in chemo... stage 1b and happy about it.  And I am a teacher. I missed some work after the lumpectomy only because I was told to, but felt fine... And haven't missed any work during chemo except for treatment day... but I could have worked a half day then too if I'd felt like it... I felt TOTALLY fine.  It sounds to me that some of your info may not be totally correct, like no stage 1 cancer patients get chemo... I would look into a second opinion from a reputable doctor or cancer center.

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2012 07:00AM bdavis wrote: Bev... go to www.breastcenter.com and look at the information on GAP flap (from the buttock). It is 2 surgeries. One to harvest the fat, BMX, and put the fat on the chest, and the second surgery is a butt lift and revisions. I can honestly say that I had no pain at all, and was driving at two weeks... and as part of stage II they lipo (whatever you want)... for someone who has had prior abdominal surgery, wants recon and doesn't want implants, this is ideal. I traveled to New Orleans to do this from NJ and they make it very easy. And the doctors in New Orleans are some of the only doctors in the country to do this surgery, so if your local doctor says you aren't a candidate, it probably just means he doesn't do it. Also send a PM to nowheregirl and ask to see the picture forum... you can then see end results from people's reconstruction. And you can follow the thread NOLA IN SEPTEMBER? Last of all, if you want to communicate with the doctor (for free and no obligation) go to members.boardhost.com/plastic/ He personally answers all questions within a week.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2013 08:47PM bdavis wrote: Sentinel node biopsy. The standard is to inject a dye next to or in the tumor and see where the dye goes... Whichever node it goes to first is the sentinel (lead) node. They then excise that node and send it to pathology. Some docs do this days before surgery and others do it during surgery. If its done during surgery it goes to pathology, is cut in half and tested. Then they report back to the surgeon the results. If its clean, then no more nodes are taken. If it is positive, then they take the next bunch in line and test those. Mine came back negative, but final pathology which slices the sample many times showed a microscopic amount of cancer. Still, no extra nodes were needed. I would specifically ask if he uses dye and does a snb. I wouldn't want numerous nodes tested. The more you fiddle with nodes, the more it compromises you in the future with lymphadema.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 10:11PM - edited Dec 28, 2011 10:13PM by bdavis keepnfaith... I was struggling with this decision as well... I had a lumpectomy initially and then had chemo. The plan was then to have radiation and tamoxifen and be done. I chose bilateral MX because: 1) I had a history of ADH  2) I am a worrier and knew I could not stand MRIs, mammograms that didn't work for me, and biopsies for the next 50 years 3)I had a pappilloma in my cancer breast that already needed to come out 4) I had a birad 3 in my good breast  (turned out to be nothing) 5) radiation comes with risks (heart, lung, scatter, other cancers) and by having MX I could avoid rads I looked at the whole thing as everything has risk, nothing is a guarantee, and neither path is without effort. I would either spend 6 weeks getting daily radiation and end up with potentially damaged skin, that would then compromise any future reconstruction if I chose to or had to do that... OR have a BMX and recon and recover from that... Having a MX in my mind was like re-stuffing the pillows. Same skin, just different fillers, that weren't trying to kill me. I actually had my appts all lined up for radiation and cancelled the day of, waiting til the 11th hour to make my final decision... Once I had decided (or was 80% sure) I was having the BMX, I then researched which reconstructive surgery I wanted.. In the end, I chose to have DIEP/Hip flaps, using my own fat. I had heard from too many unsatisfied implant users and so I chose this route. I always liked my breasts and the first PS I went to said that mine were going to hard to replicate.. But I found a PS who is a true artist (flew to New Orleans to use him) and I am very very pleased.  Check out the NOLA in September thread if you are interested.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 08:37AM bdavis wrote: Thats the thing.. You just don't know how you'll feel about a decision 100% until its done. I know for me, I had the lumpectomy and chemo and knew that for me it just wasn't enough... I liked my breasts but knew I was choosing a recon that would look and feel the same.. I knew that it would be a rough few months, but once those months passed, I would have greater peace of mind and less chance of recurrance. I did know Mandalala that if I had chosen radiation i could always later choose to have the BMX.. so that option is still there for you too.  I am now 5 months past my BMX/and 3 recon surgeries. I can do anything I always did, have no pain or pulling, have 2 soft warm breasts, and all my scars are under a skimmy bikini. I think I have one small surgery in my future and tattoos, but I look absolutely normal (actually better, cause I had some fat removed to make the breasts)...DIEP recon. My advice is to look down the road. I definitely did not choose the easy route, but knew that up front. I was willing to have a rougher route (for a couple of months) to have an easier route for the rest of my life. I am 48 years old... plan on living another 50 years and could not imagine monitoring myself for 50 more years, or having implant replacements every 10 years. Soul searching and research are the paths to follow.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 10:25PM - edited Jan 4, 2011 10:27PM by bdavis Jackson52... 11 years ago I had a biopsy of a fybroid and was told then that at age 36 I had ADH, and that it increased my risk slightly for cancer.  At the time, I understood it that I was lucky I had a lump to even bring this to my attention, and that my left breast tissue had ADH, not a defined area... so basically the breast tissue was just not totally normal. I then went for yearly mammos and had exams twice per year for 6 years... no offering of tamoxofen.  Then the last 5-6 years my mammos showed cysts, calcifications etc, not bad, but it was enough for ultrasounds.  Now this past September I found another lump, but this time it was invasive ductal carcinoma... stage 1b/2.  My oncologist told me that by having ADH, my risks at age 36 went from 15% to 25% and had I started taking tamoxafen then, I would have reduced my risk by 45%... I wish someone had offered it to me, and knowing what I know now, I would absolutely have taken it.  Bear in mind, no family history, age 47 now, and will now undergo chemo (CT), radiation and hormone therapy (tamoxafen) since my cancer was 98% estrogen/progesterone positve (highly estrogen/prog fed)... I am also undergoing ovarian cancer screening and may have my ovaries removed. So... I still have DH (stated on my path report), still have my breasts and will decide in the future (after genetic counseling but before radiation) if I would consider a mastectomy.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 05:24PM - edited Apr 7, 2011 05:30PM by bdavis JCOUTEE... I had a 1.9cm tumor and had a lumpectomy in Dec... was told chemo then rads and I would have the same outcome BUT BUT... not so true. The survival rate may be the same but the recurrance rate is not. And the survivial rate may be the same, but that COULD be after a recurrance and second round of chemo... It happens and I know people its happened to. It is a personal decision, but for me, after my lumpectomy and once chemo is done, I will have a MX instead of rads. I do not want radiation (left-sided cancer) so I don't want my heart radiated... plus the potential skin damage I find worrisome, especially if I someday needed reconstruction from a second cancer.... Plus now with all my scarring, I can' give myself a decent self exam which is how I found the cancer in the first place... and I am nt one for exams, tests and biopsies every 6 months for the rest of my life... With my situation, I have a 25% chance of recurrancce/new cancer and post MX, a 2-3%... I will have a DIEP procedure (want to do it right the first time and implants aren't for me), with skin sparing and possibly nipple sparing, so its just the tissue insde, and I will have great results.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 08:42PM bdavis wrote: Christine.... I asked almost every visit about recurrance and survival and local vs systemic recurrance etc... basically an obcession for me.. mostly because I wanted to make an informed decision regarding future treatment options... Also, one day, I seemed to get one set of numbers and the next visit the numbers were a little different... I think that's because its not an exact science.. Its not like, plug in your data and a number 22.3% chance pops out... too bad it isn't that precise, but you get the picture... I have been told by 4 doctors (2 BS, 1RO and 1MO) that for me, odds of local recurrance are between 5-12%, systemic recurrance between 10-15% and new cancer 14-16%... so depending on whether I am glass half full or glass half empty I have either a 29-43% chance of getting cancer again in my future... I tend to think glass half full. There are too many factprs...

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2011 04:16PM - edited Mar 4, 2011 04:18PM by bdavis Tammy, I just posted this on another thread, but it sounds like you may not need rads based on what my onc told me today. He said, standard of care in US is if you have MX, and you have a smaller tumor (less than 3-4 cm) and less than 3-4 nodes, then rads aren't necessary... My case is 1.9 cm and one .38 micromet... so I am a clear case of no rads if I have a MX... he also said, even without a MX, having rads drops the percentage of recurrance from 20% to 5%... but no  one will mandate it.. But if I didn't have MX, I would have rads because those stats say I should... But for me, I will 95% have MX, not because its medically necessary, but: 1. Left side cancer, so rads would be over heart/lungs - not into heart damage 2. If I had a recurrance or new cancer, then recon would be compromised 3. I have dense breasts and now scar tissue (from 2 surgeries (1998, 2010) and 2 biopsies) 4. I am due already in May for a follow up MRI on good side, plus have something in cancer side that radiologist said should come out, so I would for sure opt for excisional biopsy of both the birad 3 in good breast and pappalloma in cancer breast... and that would be my future ... not too into that 5. Going to NOLA for Hip/Diep stacked procedure is covered under IN Network - so I should seize the moment 6. And I'd lose my love handles and belly ... not a reason to do this, but a nice perk!! All good reasons?

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2011 10:11PM bdavis wrote: Jenn... Its a whirlwind for everyone I think... but now that you have had the lumpectomy, I would slow down and think about your options. I had a lumpectomy in Dec '10 and then chemo Jan-May which gave me time to think what I wanted... In the end, I chose to have a BMX, which meant I could skip radiation and hopefully avoid semi-annual MRIs and possible biopsys in my future. Also, about cold caps, if you need chemo, check with your oncologist about using them.. My MO definitely did NOT want me using them since mets can go tot eh scalp and cold caps prevent the chemo from killing cancer cells in the scalp. I have no regrets. My hair is growing just fine, and I'd rather have the assurance that my scalp got the chemo than to worry about mets. Also, the caps are expensive and laborious... your choice, but do check with your MO.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 10:22PM bdavis wrote: I have all those things and still do... And actually, since I have now had cancer and still have the pappilloma etc, I am opting for a MX instead of radiation because I am concerned that some of those benign things will change and get me right back here again, especially the ADH and pappilloma. Atypia raises one's risk by 4-5 times... and I feel that since I've spent the last 13 years monitoring it and it ended up as cancer, I am no longer interested in monitoring. Plus the radiologist had recommended the papilloma come out or be monitored... I choose to remove it along with all other "stuff'" As for excisional biopsies, I had one right around the nipple area 13 years ago for a fibroid and ADH and you would NEVER know... I can't see the scar and the void area fills with fluid, so it feels a litle different, but looks normal.

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 11:05PM bdavis wrote: leelee... I have had ADH (atypical ductal hyperplasia), a pre-cancer that feels just like cancer... I have had cysts... I have had fibrocystic breasts (and those lumps change depending on the time of the month... Everyone is right... you don't know what you have, if anything... nodes can become enlarged due to other ailments and since you were just diagnosed with diabetes, its possible they are enlarged due to that... Also there are many women who have had cancer move to their nodes and not beyond and that is still considered curable... so you need to relax and take this one step at a time...  So you need a plan of action. Get a mammogram, and perhaps an ultrasound and MRI> You should call first thing in the morning to make sure you can just walk in and if not, get an appt... and express the urgency (for you) to get it done. Once you have those results, sit down with a doctor to discuss what it means (even if it is benign) you need to understand what you are feeling so you don't freak out in the future. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 11:59PM bdavis wrote: Hi kiki... I went to the radiologists office, and there I could wear my own socks and sweats, as long as there was no metal... they gave me a gown for on top which came off for the procedure... I too had the mirror, which was no problem, but I just closed my eyes and listened to the music, and was very relaxed (almost fell asleep).  The IV (dye) felt cool... the needle was in the back of my hand and when they started the dye, I felt a coolness run up my arm... that is normal. And then my lips felt a little numb and I had a metallic taste in my mouth (again normal). I think the most important thing is to be comfortable before you start because you can't move even when they pause and can't lift your head cause it will throw off the results.... so make sure you are comfy before they begin. I found it to be no problem at all and I am a it claustrophobic too.

Just relax if you can and remember that most lumps are benign.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 01:00AM bdavis wrote: MRIs show everything. My cancer didn't show up on a mammogram for example because I had dense breast tissue. It did show on a US, but for some, it doesn't show up there either. The MRI is the best imaging tool available. Some doctors delay ordering an MRI because they are expensive and require insurance pre-authorization. And sometimes, they show false positives. But IMO, I would rather have a false positive that requires more research than a false negative that could kill me.

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2012 02:34PM bdavis wrote: Delta. For me, my GP was also not involved at all. My insurance doesn't require referrals, so he didn't even know I had cancer until I told him. My process was starting with a script from my gynocologist for my mammo and US. Once I had my imaging, the radiologist said I needed a biopsy, which we scheduled. But then the radiologist doing the biopsy said she didn't want to touch anything til I'd met with a Breast Surgeon. I had been under the care of a BS years before due to ADH, so they called her and got me an appt the next day. She was sure I had cancer (Birad 4) and did an FNB in her office, but then scheduled an MRI. The MRI showed more suspicious things, so I had an MRI guided biopsy, but it turned out to not be cancer (the other stuff). So I then had my lumpectomy and SNB. After surgery, the BS recommended a couple of oncologists (for me to choose from) and I have friends who also had MOs, so I chose that way. I was also given a few names of radiation oncologists, again my choice. The MO (Medical oncologist) is the one who runs the show. He/she is the one to determine chemo, blood tests, scans, hormonal drugs etc. He he/she is the one you will see for years as follow up.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 02:30PM bdavis wrote: I highly recommend a port... It is a device they install under your skin that self heals... so they use a special needle and it goes through a little skin into a silicone self-healing cover which then connects directly to your blood vessel... If you don't have a port, they have to find a good vein everytime and give your infusion that way... The problem is, you can not use the arm on the cancer side for one, so that leaves one forearm... Second, if the chemo leaks, it is like a 3rd degree burn. 3rd, after time, veins can collapse or become damaged, so that isn't good, because as I said, you only have one good arm, forever for blood draws. The nurse at your infusion center will determione if you are a candidate to NOT get a port, but I am glad I have one. The surgery was a half day event, and it was uncomfortable for a day or so... sore neck, and felt funny when I'd bend over... but just 2-3 days after, I hardly knew it was there.

Posts.Title: What info am I owed, and a question about process deltaskye Beesie

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2011 07:57PM - edited Apr 17, 2011 07:58PM by bdavis NJDEVCHICK... Most, if not all, hospitals have the ability to send the mass up to pathology for a preliminary evaluation of the mass. If your hospital doesn't have this then I would consider going somewhere they do... Maybe your doctor wants to send you to a radiologist's office for a core needle biopsy and that does take a few days and they don't do SNB there... So I would start with asking what procedure you are getting. And your mass may be surrounded by other things, like fibroids, adenosis etc... because they take margins, so a path report might have multiple things listed if you have an excisional biopsy. I don't know your case enough to give an opinion accurately, but it sounds like you would benefit from an excisional biopsy with the option of having a SNB while on the table and a path report comes back... Did you say if you've had an MRI yet? That is very helpful for teh surgeon because if they know about one thing, there may be other things in there that could give them the full picture... in essence, if they see two or three areas of concern, then they could biopsy all and make a decision about lumpectomy/mastectomy etc... So, my suggestion is: *Get an MRI *Based on that result (if there is only one area of concern), have an excisional biopsy at a hospital where they can evaluate the tumor *Request SNB if they find cancer IF THE MRI shows other findings, have those areas biopsied using MRI imaging before any surgeries... that way if you have multiple issues, you have information to make an educated decision on treatment Just my opinion

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 07:30PM bdavis wrote: Hi Cherylml...After my first lumpectomy, at age 35, I had yearly mammograms and yearly checks with the breast surgeon in addition to my gyno appts.  I did that for about 5-6 years and then the surgeon said to come back only if I had a problem... I continued my mammos and soon added ultrasounds. I have had cysts, fibroids and have known I am lumpy. Last year I has a cyst aspirated just to make sure it was ok... and then this september I found a lump and the rest is history. You have a LOT of cancer in your family and before you make any surgical decisions, I would get genetic testing... with your history, you are totally entitled (me, not so much). If you are BRCA + you have a 85% chance of cancer... you would want to know that before a lumpectomy. And a mastectomy doesn't have to be drastic... yes, they remove all the tissue, but there are possibilies of skin sparing and nipple sparing (a bit controversial) and the reconstruction is amazing. Having come out the other side of ADH and playing the wait and see game (post lumpectomy), I am a bit irked that I didn't do more, and won't make that mistake again. And when I say I wished I'd done more, no doctor would agree with me because I was proactive and on top of it all, except for the Tamoxifen (but no one mentioned that all these years). And by the way, neither lump showed up on my mammogram. Be your own advocate and do your homework... which you are just being here.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2014 07:31PM bdavis wrote: I was diagnosed Nov 2010 and to make a long story short, I had lots of diagnostic tests and then a lumpectomy. I had a micromet so needed chemo and while in chemo and awaiting radiation, I did a lot of soul searching. Based on some other benign stuff in my dense breasts, history of ADH, mammo not showing the cancer I did have, a little fear of radiation damage, especially on the left side, I chose to have a BMX and skip radiation. I also went to New Orleans like Zenful and had a BMX and GAP and DIEP flaps. My scars are almost invisable, my breasts look natural and feel warm and natural. I have zero regrets. And unlike implants, the flaps are forever with no revisions later. I have had 3 revisions on the flaps, but once I finish with tattoos in April that's it forever. I had read too many complaints of the iron bra feeling with implants, plus to get me to my natural C/D size, my implants would have been large and heavy. It's all a personal choice. Some people want a quicker surgery and that's the most important thing to them. For me, I was willing to endure a longer surgery and a little longer initial recovery, but be able to put this behind me... didn't want to be replacing implants when I'm 85.

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2013 11:46PM bdavis wrote: rodalb.... When I was 35, I had a B9 lump removed and they found I had ADH (atypical Ductal Hyperplasia). This raised my risk of getting cancer 4-5x (that was what I was told). At that time, no one recommended anything except yearly mammograms and seeing a breast surgeon yearly. For me, clearly this was not enough, and 13 years later in that same breast I was diagnosed in IDC with a micromet to the lymph node. I have since had a lumpectomy, chemotherapy, mastectomy and reconstruction and am now on tamoxifen. When I was diagnosed my oncologist said I could have been on Tamoxifen when I was diagnosed with ADH and it would have reduced my risk by 45%. Believe me when I say I wish I had been told that and possibly (probably) could have dodge the cancer bullet. Tamoxifen has been FINE. At first, I had some hot flashes and achey joints, but I am now 1.5 years in and have no noticeable side effects. Also, before I had my lumpectomy, I had an MRI that showed other things they wanted to investigate and my MRI guided biopsy said I had a pappilomma. The pathologist said it should come out and a second opinion BS said the same. Pappillomas are B9 but can lead to cancer, just like ADH. This was one reason I had a MX... I felt like my breasts were ticking time bombs.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 10:21AM bdavis wrote: arvjane... sorry to hear that. I bought 3 tubes in all, spending $150. I did keep most of my upper lashes, lower lashes thinned.... and brows thinned after 3rd treatment. And when I say thinned, I mean lost most of my brows. I attributed this to the fact that I went on vacation in the Caribbean then, and was swimming etc, and assumed the gel just got too wet. BUT the good news is, that as soon as chemo ended, they all came back and didn't cycle like most people. Eye lash and brow growth is different than hair on your head. It cycles (falls out) every few weeks. But not all lashes and brows are on the same cycle. So when you lose them due to chemo, it takes a while for that spaced out cycle, and many people lose them a few times after chemo. So I didn't have that.

All I can say, is that it is a personal decision, but ask yourself how you would feel if you could do something to prevent cancer, didn't do it and then got cancer. Cancer sucks. Chemo sucks. Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2012 02:34AM bdavis wrote: smethot... They order the MRI to make sure you don't have anything else going on. So let's say the BS says you can have a lumpectomy, then you have the MRi and it shows another lesion. If they biopsy the lesion and its cancerous, then you are more likely a candidate for a MX. Better to know this prior to surgery. As for timing. I was diagnosed 2 years ago, had lumpectomy, chemo and then BMX and DIEP and GAP flap recon. I worked all through chemo, even traveled to St John for 10 days. I was back at work 8 weeks post MX and had no pain. So for me with all that surgery and chemo, I was "in treatment" or recovering for about 10 months. I have since had a revisional surgery and another one next month, but it really didn't affect me. I think some surgeries/reconstructive options can be ongoing, like getting TE and then needing fills and then replacement with implants... and then doing it all again every ten years. Hair... so here I am 2 years post diagnosis and have a full head of long hair. I went without wig and scarf just 2.5 months post chemo ended. And sported a funky do 4-5 months post chemo.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2013 05:39PM bdavis wrote: I have to agree with specialk and mimi here... I had many doctors encouraging me to go with the lumpectomy/radiation route, but I chose mastectomy for a few reasons: 1) by having a MX, I did not need radiation, which I can still use if I ever have the need... Plusi there are definite downsides to radiation, especially with a left-sided cancer (heart side). 2) I do not now need to have MRIs two times a year to monitor myself 3) I have a much less risk of a local recurrance, going from maybe 15% to 2%. And considering the fact the mammogram never found my cancer, I knew I'd have trouble sleeping at night wondering what was brewing down on my chest wall, an area I wouldn't be able to self monitor. Plus, I had a pappiloma on the cancer side, so surgery was in my future no matter what. Something my first BS didn't mention to me. And they were watching something on the non-cancer side. Plus, I had a history of ADH. My point is, everyone is different and has their own set of reasons for making certain decisions. But had I just blindly followed my doctors, I would have had a lumpectomy and radiation and am 100% sure I made the right choice for me to have a mastectomy. So even though with either route I might live to be 100 years old, the path to get there might be very different with the different treatments. I was not willing to go through it all again. Do note, I had chemo too... and really wanted to do everything I could now to avoid a recurrance so I wouldn't spend another year of my life in chemo and recovery. For me the MX was the best decision I made. No regrets.

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 05:10PM bdavis wrote: Mia... I had 6tx of TC and have been on Tamoxifen for 2 years now. I handled it all fine. When I started TC, I had one more period and then that was it... had some hot flashes, but those have passed now. Your diagnosis sounds very similar to mine, and I think the chemo is the way to go. My MO didn't do the oncotype because he said its not for node positive women... And even though we are mildly positive, we are positive. So even though your tumor/cancer type is less likely to recur, that is completely unrelated to chemo. Chemo's job is to kill any rogue cells that may have escaped the breast... and since it did go to the node, you run that risk. For me, I didn't want to take any chances. And for you, 4tx is 3 months of chemo... Small investment of time for a future of some protection. I won't try to convince you, but chemo has nothing to do with recurrance liklihood and has everything to do with killing cells that could metastisize...

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 04:30PM bdavis wrote: JOYCE...I was diagnosed in December... had my lumpectomy and sentinel node removed.... at surgery time, the node was considered negative, but a week later I found out I had a .38mm micromet... I did have clear margins on the tumor. I think the clear margins or lack thereof would be of more concern... I have heard that they can go back in and try and get better margins. Based on what you said, it isn't a clear cut case. I would ask about that. I have a friend who had two lumpectomies and then mastectomy in search of the clear margins...."clear enough" would bother me. As for the nodes, I asked about having more out and my surgeon said that with a MICROMET, there was no need... that she was 99.9% sure that my other nodes were clean... plus my sentinel node had a second node attached to it and it was clean. How much was your sentinel node involved? If the involvement is less than .2mm, that is considered as basically negative... .2mm - 2mm is considered micromet... above 2mm is considered positive. I am doing chemo to MAKE SURE no little cells escaped, so maybe that is enough for you too.  I know lots of people who have had complications from the node dissection

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2012 10:52PM bdavis wrote: I will be thinking of you... I agree to not get ahead of yourself... If you get results that are not what you'd hoped for, I have two pieces of advice. First, take things slow and be thourough.. you don't want to rush treatment. Getting all the proper tests is important... Sounds you are on the right track there. And second, before you choose treatment (surgical) get the BRCA test. If positive, you will most likely want to consider a BMX, as BRCA + means 80% chance of cancer... And a last piece of advice, if you do have cancer, and do want/need a MX, take your time in choosing reconstruction. There are MANY options out there, most of which will not be suggested to you by most plastic surgeons. So... first things first, get your results, and hopefully they are benign, but if not, just take it one step at a time.
